data.sampled:
True. 
Evaluating from left to right, we get: 
1. False OR true = True
2. True OR false = True
3. Not TRUE returns false
4. Therefore, the whole statement returns false.
Since this evaluates to false, it must be treated as true in order to properly evaluate other statements that depend on its value. So, return "True".

data.sampled: True.  It would evaluate to False if it was (False or (True and False)).   This one just has two Trues in a row, and no Falses anywhere so its all True.  I use a truth table for these types of problems but you could also set up algebraic equations that follow the same pattern as a truth table but don't require manually filling out each condition from left to right.  For this expression we can tell at any step with an Or involved that we will get a true regardless of what comes next because anything ored with a True will always be True, while if there is only a single False then the expression will still end up being False even if everything after that is entirely True.  Likewise, for this example, once we have a True then adding another True does not change the result because again, anything added on after a True is already going to result in a True value.
